content: Cabinet of Singapore from 2006 to 2011 The **Second Cabinet of Lee Hsien Loong** of the [Government](/wiki/Government_of_Singapore) of [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore) was sworn into office on 30 May 2006, following the [2006 general election](/wiki/2006_Singaporean_general_election) for the [11th Parliament](/wiki/11th_Parliament_of_Singapore). As was the case previously, the Cabinet was made up exclusively of Members of Parliament from the governing [People's Action Party](/wiki/People%27s_Action_Party) (PAP). ## Initial composition Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong made few changes in his administration. In the only change at the ministerial level, [Raymond Lim](/wiki/Raymond_Lim) was promoted to be the [Minister for Transport](/wiki/Minister_for_Transport_(Singapore)) replacing [Yeo Cheow Tong](/wiki/Yeo_Cheow_Tong). Five new faces were sworn into political office, namely [Lui Tuck Yew](/wiki/Lui_Tuck_Yew), [Lee Yi Shyan](/wiki/Lee_Yi_Shyan), [Grace Fu](/wiki/Grace_Fu), [Teo Ser Luck](/wiki/Teo_Ser_Luck) and [Masagos Zulkifli](/wiki/Masagos_Zulkifli). They hold the roles of [Minister of State](/wiki/Minister_of_State) or Parliamentary secretaries in political office. [Minister for Education](/wiki/Minister_for_Education_(Singapore)) [Tharman Shanmugaratnam](/wiki/Tharman_Shanmugaratnam) was given another role as Second Minister for Finance. Transport Minister Raymond Lim relinquished his roles as Second Minister for Finance and Minister in the [Prime Minister's Office](/wiki/Prime_Minister%27s_Office_(Singapore)). [Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports](/wiki/Minister_for_Community_Development,_Youth_and_Sports) [Vivian Balakrishnan](/wiki/Vivian_Balakrishnan) also had a second post as [Second Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts](/wiki/Minister_for_Information,_Communications_and_the_Arts) as he relinquished his Second Minister for Trade and Industry [portfolio](/wiki/Portfolio_(government)). The Cabinet of Singapore 2006 consisted of the following persons: PortfolioMinisterPortrait[Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Singapore)[**Lee** Hsien Loong](/wiki/Lee_Hsien_Loong)[Senior Minister](/wiki/Senior_Minister_of_Singapore)[**Goh** Chok Tong](/wiki/Goh_Chok_Tong)[Minister Mentor](/wiki/Minister_Mentor)[**Lee** Kuan Yew](/wiki/Lee_Kuan_Yew)Deputy Prime Minister Acting Prime Minister in the Prime Minister's absence [Minister for Defence](/wiki/Minister_for_Defence_(Singapore)) Minister in Charge of the Civil Service [**Teo** Chee Hean](/wiki/Teo_Chee_Hean)Deputy Prime Minister [Minister for Home Affairs](/wiki/Minister_for_Home_Affairs_(Singapore)) [**Wong** Kan Seng](/wiki/Wong_Kan_Seng)[Senior Minister](/wiki/Senior_Minister_of_Singapore) [Co-ordinating Minister for National Security](/wiki/Co-ordinating_Minister_for_National_Security) [S. bold are the [surnames](/wiki/Surname) of Chinese persons, and the [personal names](/wiki/Personal_name) of Indian and Malay persons (except for Vivian Balakrishnan and Tharman Shanmugaratnam, where they indicate surnames as well). ## Reshuffles ### As of 1 April 2009 A Cabinet reshuffle took place effective as of April 2009. Professor [S. Jayakumar](/wiki/S._Jayakumar_(Singaporean_politician)) relinquished his post of Deputy Prime Minister, and was replaced by Teo Chee Hean. [Gan Kim Yong](/wiki/Gan_Kim_Yong) was appointed [Minister for Manpower](/wiki/Ministry_of_Manpower_(Singapore)) after a year as Acting Minister, and [Lim Hwee Hua](/wiki/Lim_Hwee_Hua) took up the post of Minister in the Prime Minister's Office, becoming the first woman in Singapore to become a full minister. As of 1 April 2009, the Cabinet of Singapore consisted of the following persons: PortfolioMinisterPortrait[Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Singapore)[**Lee** Hsien Loong](/wiki/Lee_Hsien_Loong)[Senior Minister](/wiki/Senior_Minister_of_Singapore)[**Goh** Chok Tong](/wiki/Goh_Chok_Tong)[Minister Mentor](/wiki/Minister_Mentor)[**Lee** Kuan Yew](/wiki/Lee_Kuan_Yew)Deputy Prime Minister Acting Prime Minister in the Prime Minister's absence [Minister for Defence](/wiki/Minister_for_Defence_(Singapore)) Minister in Charge of the Civil Service [**Teo** Chee Hean](/wiki/Teo_Chee_Hean)Deputy Prime Minister [Minister for Home Affairs](/wiki/Minister_for_Home_Affairs_(Singapore)) [**Wong** Kan Seng](/wiki/Wong_Kan_Seng)[Senior Minister](/wiki/Senior_Minister_of_Singapore) [Co-ordinating Minister for National Security](/wiki/Co-ordinating_Minister_for_National_Security) [S. bold are the [surnames](/wiki/Surname) of Chinese persons, and the [personal names](/wiki/Personal_name) of Indian and Malay persons (except for Vivian Balakrishnan and Tharman Shanmugaratnam, where they indicate surnames as well). ### As of 1 November 2010 In October 2010, a further "minor adjustment" was announced. Senior Minister S. Jayakumar relinquished his post of Co-ordinating Minister for National Security, which was taken up by Deputy Prime Minister [Wong Kan Seng](/wiki/Wong_Kan_Seng). In turn, Wong gave up his [Home Affairs](/wiki/Ministry_of_Home_Affairs_(Singapore)) portfolio in favour of Minister for Law [K. Shanmugam](/wiki/K._Shanmugam). [Lui Tuck Yew](/wiki/Lui_Tuck_Yew) was promoted to full minister in the [Ministry of Information, Communications and the Arts](/wiki/Ministry_of_Information,_Communications_and_the_Arts). Thus, as of 1 November 2010, the Cabinet of Singapore consisted of the persons listed in the table below. title: Second Lee Hsien Loong Cabinet
